content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see multiple sections of tissue on this slide, the majority of which are lymph nodes of varying sizes, embedded in adipose tissue. There are approximately 12 separate tissue pieces that appear to be lymph nodes. At this low magnification, most lymph nodes appear densely cellular and basophilic (purple), consistent with lymphoid tissue. I do not see any obvious, large, pale areas that would be highly suspicious for extensive metastatic carcinoma at this power. My initial impression is that these are likely lymph nodes from a regional dissection that need to be carefully examined for metastases.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic evaluation of each lymph node. The green box is placed at the periphery of one of the larger lymph nodes. This is a critical area to examine because the subcapsular sinus, located just under the lymph node capsule, is the first site where metastatic tumor cells typically lodge and begin to grow. Examining this interface between the lymph node and the surrounding fat is essential to look for both micrometastases within the sinus and for any evidence of extracapsular extension (tumor growth beyond the capsule into the adipose tissue), which has prognostic significance. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the primary task for these lymph node sections is to identify any evidence of metastatic disease. This requires a systematic, high-magnification examination of every lymph node on the slide. The green box is placed on one of the larger lymph nodes (the second one from the top left). I am zooming into this specific node as part of this systematic review process to assess its architecture and cellular composition and to look for any non-lymphoid, atypical cells that would suggest metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, it is standard practice to examine every piece of tissue submitted as a lymph node to accurately stage the cancer. The green box is highlighting one of the smaller lymph nodes, the second from the top, towards the center. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic review of all lymph nodes on the slide. Even small nodes can contain metastatic deposits, and a thorough evaluation of all nodes is critical for determining the patient's N (nodal) stage. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine each lymph node for evidence of metastasis. When scanning at low power, I look for architectural disruption or abnormal coloration. The area highlighted by the green box, located on the periphery of one of the smaller lymph nodes at the top (the second node from the top, to the right), shows a focal irregularity. There appears to be a breach in the smooth contour of the lymph node capsule with potential extension into the surrounding perinodal fat. This is highly suspicious for a metastatic deposit with extranodal extension, which warrants immediate high-magnification review. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my procedure is to systematically examine every single lymph node on the slide. The selected area is one of these lymph nodes (roughly the fifth one down from the top left). At low power, its architecture appears cellular with some nodularity. I would zoom into this area to assess the lymphoid architecture at higher magnification, specifically to look for preserved structures like follicles and sinuses, and to meticulously search for any atypical, non-lymphoid cells (i.e., metastatic carcinoma) that might be present. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because this lymph node, located in the lower left quadrant, shows features suspicious for metastasis even at low power. The normal architecture appears to be partially effaced (replaced). Instead of a uniform population of lymphocytes, there is a patchy, mottled appearance with intermixed darker (basophilic) and paler (eosinophilic) regions. This heterogeneity suggests that a non-lymphoid cell population, such as metastatic carcinoma, is infiltrating and replacing the native lymphoid tissue. The goal of zooming in is to examine the cellular details in these paler areas to confirm the presence of malignant cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to systematically examine every single lymph node to determine if cancer has spread. The green box is placed on one of the medium-sized lymph nodes (the fourth large node from the bottom, on the right). I would zoom into this area as part of my routine, methodical screening process. Even though it doesn't look obviously positive for metastasis at low power, a high-magnification view is essential to rule out micrometastases (small clusters of tumor cells) or isolated tumor cells, particularly in the subcapsular sinus, which is a common site for initial tumor cell deposition. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node to confirm the presence or absence of metastasis. This specific lymph node (one of the central, larger ones) is chosen for closer inspection because its low-power appearance is highly suggestive of being positive. It is enlarged and shows effacement of the normal lymph node architecture by a homogenous, basophilic infiltrate. Zooming in is necessary to examine the cytology of these infiltrating cells to confirm they are malignant epithelial cells (carcinoma) and not a lymphoid proliferation (lymphoma) or a reactive process. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am examining the largest lymph node, located in the bottom right of the slide. The zoom is directed towards the periphery of the main lymphoid aggregate. This is a standard approach because metastatic cells transported via lymphatic vessels typically first arrive and colonize the subcapsular sinus, which is located just under the capsule at the edge of the node. Examining this region is critical for detecting early or small metastatic deposits. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node on the slide. This particular zoom is on the largest lymph node, located in the bottom right quadrant. The focus is on the periphery of the node, at the interface between the lymph node capsule and the surrounding perinodal fat. This is a critical area to assess for extranodal extension (ENE), which is when tumor cells have broken through the capsule and invaded the adjacent fatty tissue. ENE is an important prognostic factor. It's also a common location (subcapsular sinus) to find early metastatic deposits. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every lymph node to check for metastases, which is crucial for cancer staging. The green box is placed on the largest lymph node in the bottom right. This node appears to be almost completely replaced by tumor. I would zoom into this area to confirm the malignant nature of the infiltrating cells, assess their morphology (e.g., glandular formation, differentiation), and confirm that it is indeed a metastatic deposit from a colorectal primary. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the standard of care requires the meticulous examination of every single lymph node to search for evidence of metastasis. The highlighted area contains one of the smaller lymph nodes located in the upper right portion of the slide. From this low power, its shape appears slightly irregular, and the staining is intensely basophilic, which warrants a closer look. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic review of all submitted nodes to determine if it is a reactive node or if it contains a metastatic tumor deposit. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the lymph node located in the bottom left corner. At low magnification, this node is highly suspicious. It has a disrupted architecture with a dense, purple cellular rim and a central, pale, somewhat 'hollowed-out' or cystic-appearing area. This pattern is suggestive of a lymph node replaced by tumor, potentially with central necrosis or degeneration. I need to examine the interface between the cellular component and the surrounding tissue at higher magnification to confirm if it's metastatic carcinoma and to assess for extranodal extension (tumor spreading beyond the lymph node capsule into the surrounding fat). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see the edge of a lymph node. The tissue consists of dense lymphoid parenchyma, including a portion of a reactive germinal center (the paler, more organized circular structure). A thin fibrous capsule separates the lymphoid tissue from the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue (fat). The subcapsular sinus, the space immediately beneath the capsule, appears clear and does not contain any atypical epithelial cells or tumor deposits. My impression of this specific area is that it is a benign, reactive lymph node, and there is no evidence of metastasis or extracapsular extension in this field of view.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a cross-section of a lymph node. The lymphoid architecture is preserved and shows features of a reactive process. There are numerous, well-defined lymphoid follicles, many with prominent, pale-staining germinal centers surrounded by darker mantle zones. This pattern is characteristic of follicular hyperplasia. The sinusoids are not clearly distended with tumor cells. I do not see any nests, glands, or single files of atypical epithelial cells to suggest metastatic carcinoma. My impression of this specific area is a reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, the normal architecture of the lymph node is effaced and replaced by a diffuse and monotonous infiltrate of small, round lymphocytes with dark, condensed chromatin and scant cytoplasm. I do not see the typical features of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma, such as atypical glands, large pleomorphic cells, or necrotic debris. Instead, the morphology is highly suggestive of a lymphoproliferative disorder, likely Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma/Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (SLL/CLL), which can be an incidental finding. My impression is that this lymph node is negative for metastatic carcinoma but is involved by a lymphoma.
This is ROI 4. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms my suspicion. The lower portion of the image shows the dense, dark-staining lymphoid tissue of the lymph node. At the edge of this node, and clearly infiltrating into the surrounding adipose tissue (seen in the upper portion), there is a cluster of atypical cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and pleomorphic nuclei, and are arranged in poorly-formed glandular structures. This morphology is consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. A key finding is that the tumor has breached the lymph node capsule and is invading the perinodal fat, which constitutes extranodal extension (ENE). My impression is a positive lymph node with metastatic adenocarcinoma showing definite extranodal extension.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the architecture of a lymph node. There are multiple, well-defined lymphoid follicles, many of which contain paler-staining germinal centers. This feature is known as follicular hyperplasia. The areas between the follicles (paracortex) are also densely populated with small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. I do not see any nests of atypical epithelial cells, abnormal gland formation, or desmoplastic stromal reaction that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node showing follicular hyperplasia. There is no evidence of metastasis in this field of view.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the lymph node parenchyma is extensively infiltrated by malignant cells. There are dense sheets of small, dark lymphocytes, which are the native cells of the lymph node. However, intermingled with and replacing these lymphocytes are nests and poorly formed glands of atypical epithelial cells. These malignant cells are larger than the lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and pleomorphic nuclei with irregular contours and coarse chromatin. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing a significant metastatic tumor deposit from a colorectal primary.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the typical architecture of a lymph node. There is a dense population of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. Prominently, there are several well-defined, rounded structures which are reactive lymphoid follicles. These follicles exhibit germinal centers (the slightly paler central areas with larger lymphocytes and tingible body macrophages) and surrounding darker mantle zones. The presence of these reactive follicles is a strong indicator of a benign process. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular formations, or nests of tumor cells that would indicate metastasis. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a dense, back-to-back proliferation of malignant glands, consistent with adenocarcinoma. The tumor cells have large, pleomorphic, and hyperchromatic nuclei with irregular nuclear contours. There is evidence of poorly formed glandular structures and significant cellular crowding. My impression is that this confirms the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma within the lymph node, making it a positive node.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense and monotonous population of small, dark, round cells with scant cytoplasm, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. These cells are part of the lymph node parenchyma. There are some lighter pink, ill-defined spaces which represent lymphatic sinuses. I do not see any atypical cells, such as large cells with irregular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, or glandular formations, that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression of this specific area is that it represents benign lymphoid tissue, and there is no evidence of metastasis in this field of view.
This is ROI 10 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image shows the edge of the lymph node parenchyma (left) and the adjacent perinodal adipose tissue (right), separated by a fibrous capsule. The lymph node tissue consists of a dense, monotonous population of small, dark lymphocytes. I am carefully inspecting the capsule and the fat for any atypical epithelial cells, either singly or in clusters/glands, which would represent metastatic carcinoma. In this specific field, I do not see any convincing evidence of metastatic tumor cells or extranodal extension. The boundary appears well-defined and 'clean'. My impression of this specific area is negative for malignancy, but I would continue to scan the entire circumference of this node and all other nodes on the slide.
This is ROI 11 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see that the normal lymph node architecture is completely effaced and replaced by a dense, back-to-back proliferation of malignant glands and solid sheets of tumor cells. The cells have large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. At the bottom of the image, poorly-formed glandular structures are more evident. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing a large metastatic deposit (macrometastasis) of adenocarcinoma, consistent with a colorectal primary.
This is ROI 12 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the architecture of a lymph node. The tissue is densely cellular, composed almost entirely of lymphocytes. The normal nodal architecture with distinct cortex and medulla is effaced. In the upper right corner, there is a suggestion of a residual lymphoid follicle. However, I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or nests of tumor cells that would be characteristic of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma. The overall features are those of a reactive lymph node, likely showing follicular and paracortical hyperplasia. My impression is that this lymph node is negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 13 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a dense infiltrate of basophilic (purple) cells on the top portion of the image. Below this, there is perinodal adipose and fibrous tissue. The interface between the dense cellular infiltrate and the surrounding fat is not smooth or well-encapsulated. Instead, there are irregular nests and clusters of the purple cells infiltrating directly into the adipose tissue. This feature is diagnostic of extranodal extension (ENE). While the cytology is not perfectly clear for definitive carcinoma in this specific field (lacks obvious glands), the massive replacement of a lymph node and the presence of ENE in the context of a known colorectal cancer makes the diagnosis of a metastatic lymph node virtually certain. My impression is a positive lymph node with extranodal extension.
